Athos da Silveira Ramos, 149 – 302/A, CEP: 21941-909, Rio de Janeiro, RJ, Brazil ⁎ Corresponding author. # Retired It is widely agreed among researchers that global warming is directly linked to increased concentrations of carbon dioxide (CO2) in the atmosphere. As such, technologies aimed at reducing CO2 emissions have been extensively studied. In this study, bimetallic (Ni-Mn, Ni-Al, Mn-Al) and trimetallic (Ni-Mn-Al) precursors were synthesized by a coprecipitation method to obtain layered double hydroxides (LDH). Preparation of the studied catalysts is easily scalable, due to the relative simplicity and reproducibility of LDH synthesis. The effects of pH and molar proportion of the metals on their physical and chemical properties were evaluated. After calcination and in-situ reduction, the oxides were evaluated as catalysts in the CO2 hydrogenation reaction, which is a possible alternative to the abatement of global warming. It was concluded that Mn increased the specific surface area of the oxides and the content of basic sites in the catalyst, as well as facilitated the onset of the materials reduction. The most active catalyst, obtained at lower pH, had only 6 mol% Mn and showed CO2 conversion and CH4 selectivity equal to 82 % and 100 % at 350 °C, respectively. It was also stable during 16 h on stream, at the temperature of maximum conversion. At low temperatures, this catalyst was one of the best reported in the literature, with CO2 conversion and CH4 selectivity of 40 % and 100 % at 225 °C, respectively. Additionally, 50 % conversion was achieved at 248 °C (T50). At temperatures higher than 400 °C, the reverse water gas shift reaction, which competes with methanation, was inhibited in solids with higher Mn contents (≥ 40 mol%). Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Ni-Mn-Al mixed oxides Layered Double Hydroxides Methanation CO2 valorization Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The catalytic hydrogenation of carbon dioxide, also called Sabatier reaction or CO2 methanation (Reaction 1), has been used since 1902 [1]. The main product is methane, known as synthetic natural gas (SNG) [2]. Recently, the reaction has attracted attention due to its potential to mitigate global warming. It prevents the accumulation in the atmosphere of the CO2 produced during methane combustion (Reaction 2), creating a circular process. However, green hydrogen must be used to ensure the sustainability of the process [3]. In addition to the environmental issues, the production of SNG has attracted attention because this fuel has high energy density, easy storage and has an already implemented distribution network (gas pipelines). CO2(g) + 4H2(g) ↔ CH4(g) + 2H2O(g), ΔH° = -146 kJ mol−1 (Reaction 1) CH4(g) + O2(g) ↔ CO2(g) + 2H2O(g), ΔH° = -74 kJ mol−1 (Reaction 2) Because of its exothermicity, CO2 methanation is thermodynamically favored at low temperatures, an unfavorable condition for the kinetics. Moreover, CO2 is a stable molecule, challenging the development of catalysts [4,5]. Traditionally, hydrogenation reactions, including the Sabatier reaction, are carried out over catalysts containing precious metals, especially Ru, Rh, Pt and Pd, leading to conversions close to 100 % [6]. However, the search for non-precious metal catalysts is encouraged by economic and environmental aspects and has driven the development of alternative catalysts based on non-noble transition metals, such as Ni [7,8] and Co [9]. They present advantages such as lower cost and greater abundance. Furthermore, transition metals with low oxidation state usually increase the basicity of materials [10]. As CO2 is activated on basic sites, the basicity plays a fundamental role in the reaction mechanism [2,11]. Cobalt and nickel can be used as bulk catalysts or deposited on a support, achieving activities as high as those of precious metals under the same conditions [6]. However, they are susceptible to deactivation by sintering or coke deposition with increasing temperature [4,12]. Furthermore, the increase in temperature favors the reverse water-gas shift (RWGS) reaction, producing CO and H2O (Reaction 3) and resulting in a drop in methane selectivity [2,13]. CO2(g) + H2(g) ↔ CO (g) + H2O(g), ΔH° = 41.2 kJ mol−1 (Reaction 3) These disadvantages, as well as the thermodynamic and kinetic limitations, address the research to the development of stable catalysts with high activity and selectivity at low temperatures. In this context, layered double hydroxides (LDH), also known as hydrotalcite-type materials, have been studied as catalyst precursors for CO2 hydrogenation. When calcined, the precursors produce mixed oxides with high surface areas, basicity, thermal stability and high dispersion of the active species [14,15]. LDH have the general formula M2+ 1-x N3+ x (OH−)2 A n− x/n.mH2O, where M2+ and N3+ correspond to divalent and trivalent cations, respectively, A n− is an anion of charge -n, x is the trivalent metal molar fraction relative to total metals, and m is the amount of hydration water in the interlayer region. The materials are prepared by simple methods, allowing different combinations and relative proportions of metals, with various interlayer anions, which can generate unique properties in the catalysts [16]. There are several studies concerning the use of catalysts obtained from LDH for CO2 methanation. For instance, Abate et al. [17] compared oxides obtained from Ni-Al LDH with alumina-supported Ni. The first one presented higher activity and thermal stability due to higher metal dispersion and surface area. When derived from trimetallic Ni-Mg-Al LDH, the improvement in catalytic activity was associated with the Ni-MgO interface, where Ni promotes hydrogenation and MgO promotes CO2 adsorption [7]. There are also studies related to the use of LDH-derived oxides promoted with rare earths (Ni-Ce-Al), where Ce increased the reducibility of Ni species, the oxygen vacancies concentration and the sites with moderate basic strength, improving catalytic activity [14,18]. Manganese oxides, which are low cost and highly abundant materials, have been considered as potential promoters for CO2 hydrogenation. For example, Ni/bentonite modified with Mn promoted CO2 activation and improved catalytic activity at low temperature [19]. Vrijburg et al. [6,20] evaluated the activity of NiMn/TiO2 and NiMn/Al2O3 and found that the oxophilic nature of defect sites on MnO facilitated the activation of CO2 over NiMn/TiO2, while on NiMn/Al2O3, the addition of Mn increased nickel dispersion and reducibility, and therefore the adsorption/activation of CO2. Varga et al. [9] reported that MnO in cobalt-based catalyst inhibited the concurrent reaction to methanation at high temperatures, generating an 100 % methane-selective catalyst at 400 °C. Tamimi et al [4] evaluated the influence of several metal oxides (Fe, Cr, Co and Mn) on the properties of Ni-Al2O3 catalysts and concluded that MnO promoted the highest reducibility and adsorption of CO2, generating the most active and stable catalyst. Xiao et al. [5] produced Ni-Mn-Mg-Al LDH and observed that Mn increased the catalytic activity by increasing CO2 adsorption capacity and metal reducibility, with a positive correlation being found between moderate strength basic sites and activity. Considering previous studies, it is believed that Ni-Mn-Al LDH can generate catalysts with higher active phase dispersion, reducibility, and basicity than in other systems. Examples of those systems reported in the literature are Ni and Mn catalysts supported on silica-modified boehmite [20] catalysts obtained from bimetallic LDH in the Ni-Al system [17], or obtained from trimetallic LDH in the Ni-Mg-Al system [7]. As far as we know, trimetallic catalysts obtained from Ni-Mn-Al LDH have not yet been evaluated in the CO2 methanation reaction. In addition, the Ni-Mn-Al LDH has not yet been synthesized by the coprecipitation method using ammonium hydroxides and ammonium carbonate [NH4OH e (NH4)2CO3]. These compounds have the advantage of not leaving extraneous residues in the solids, such as Na+ or K+, which are not removed in the calcination step and may cause a loss of activity in the reaction studied. The present work intends to evaluate the influence of phase composition and structural parameters of reduced Ni-Mn-Al materials (obtained from their corresponding LHD precursors) on their physicochemical properties and their catalytic performance in the CO2 methanation reaction at low temperatures. These solids were prepared as bimetallic and trimetallic systems, varying the metal proportions and pH in the second case. Furthermore, ex-situ characterizations of the catalyst and Rietveld refinement allowed the study of the physicochemical properties of reduced materials. Finally, this work addresses a simple, low-cost and scalable method for producing a catalyst for the CO2 methanation reaction, whose technology has great industrial and environmental relevance, as it generates a synthetic fuel compatible with the engines and distribution lines already implemented, therefore it is easily absorbed by the market; and is still seen as a way to minimize CO2 emissions into the atmosphere, mitigating global warming. 2 Experimental 2.1 Samples preparation Ni(NO3)2.6H2O (Vetec), Al(NO3)3.9H2O (Isofar), Mn(NO3)2.9H2O (diluted in HNO3, Sigma Aldrich), NH4(OH) (Vetec) and (NH4)2CO3 (Vetec) were used for the synthesis of LDH by coprecipitation at constant pH. The pH control was carried out using a Provitec pH controller. Potentiometric titration (detailed explanations can be seen in the supplementary material) were previously performed to define the pH conditions, where pH 6.5 ± 0.1 was established for the bimetallic Ni-Al precursor and pH 8 ± 0.1 for the precursors with Mn. To analyze the pH effect, one of the Ni-Mn-Al precursor was also synthesized at pH 6.5 ± 0.1 and named Ni3MnAl-pH6.5. The pH control was performed by dripping two solutions (50 mL each) into a reactor containing 200 mL of deionized water at 70 ºC. One of the solutions (0.5 M of metals) contained Ni, Mn and Al nitrates and the other one, ammonium hydroxide (1.1 M) and ammonium carbonate (0.12M). At the end of the addition of the solutions, the suspension was filtered and the solid was washed with deionized water until the pH of the deionized water. The material was then dried at 100 °C for 3 h. The molar composition of the synthesis mixture was Y Ni2+ : Z Mn2+ : 20 Al3+ : 220 OH− : 24 CO3 2−, where nickel (Y) and Mn (Z) proportions were varied along with the quantity of the elements. The bimetallic and trimetallic precursors were identified as Ni4Al-pH6.5, Ni4Mn-pH8, Mn4Al-pH8, Ni2Mn2Al-pH8, Ni3MnAl-pH8 and Ni3MnAl-pH6.5. The nomenclature and synthesis conditions were listed in Table S1 of the Supplementary Material. The catalysts were obtained in two sequential steps: the calcination of precursors to form oxides and the in-situ reduction of oxides to generate reduced Ni and Mn species. Fig. 1 presents a schematic of the process of obtaining the catalysts. The conditions were shown in Table 1 . The calcined and reduced materials were named as the precursors plus the suffixes "c" and "r", respectively. For ex-situ characterization, the catalysts were passivated after reduction, as described in Table 1. The passivation of the reduced materials was essential because they oxidized spontaneously upon exposure to air, making it impossible to characterize them with our available equipment. XRD analysis was performed to assess whether passivation altered the catalyst structure. In addition, reference materials (monometallic nickel and manganese oxides) were also characterized. The first one was obtained from the calcination of nickel nitrate under the conditions described in Table 1 while the other one was acquired from Merck. They were named NiO and MnO2, respectively. 2.2 Samples Characterization The characterization methods are briefly described below. Additional information is detailed in the Supplementary Material. X-ray diffraction (XRD) of the materials was performed in a Bruker D8 Advance powder diffractometer, using CuKα radiation (λ = 1.5406 Å), 0.02° step−1 and 5 s step−1. The crystalline phases were identified using the PDF (Powder Diffraction File) database of the ICDD (International Centre for Diffraction Data). To evaluate the trivalent metal content in LDH and quantify the phases present in precursors, calcined and reduced materials, Rietveld refinement was carried out using the TOPAS 6.0 software. With the results of the refinement of the reduced oxides, the nickel degree of reduction (α) and Ni surface area (SNi ) were calculated. The details of the calculations are shown in the Supplementary Material. The morphology and size distribution of the nanoparticles were determined in a high-resolution microscopic Jeol 2100F 200kV TEM-FEG instrument, operating at 200 kV. Electron diffraction patterns were also collected to investigate the crystalline phases in the samples. The data were processed in the Digital Micrograph software. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM-FEG) analyses of the precursors were performed on a Jeol JSM-7100F microscope operating at 5 kV. The elemental analysis of the calcined materials was carried out by inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectroscopy (ICP-AES) using a Spectro Arcos spectrometer. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed in a simultaneous thermal analyzer model SDT 600 from TA Instruments, under the conditions indicated in Table 1. The FTIR spectra were acquired in a Perkin-Elmer instrument, Frontier model between 400 and 4000 cm−1, with 2 cm−1 resolution and the samples dispersed in KBr pellets. The surface areas of the calcined materials were determined by the BET method from N2 adsorption/desorption, using a Micromeritics ASAP model 2020 instrument in the relative pressure range of 0.05 to 0.3. H2 temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) and CO2 temperature-programmed desorption (CO2-TPD) experiments were performed using a Micromeritics Autochem II model 2920 equipment coupled to a Pfeiffer Omni Star GSD320 quadrupole mass spectrometer. In H2-TPR, calcined samples (approximately 200 mg) were pretreated before reduction (the experimental conditions are shown in Table 1). In CO2-TPD, in addition to pretreatment and reduction, the samples were submitted to purge under inert gas, CO2 adsorption and finally CO2 desorption under programmed temperature (see Table 1). 2.3 Catalysts evaluation CO2 methanation over the catalysts was performed in a quartz reactor inside a vertical furnace (PID temperature control) coupled to an Agilent 7890A chromatograph provided with GasPro and molecular sieve 5A columns. Before the reaction, the oxides were reduced in situ with H2. The reaction was carried out over 50 mg of calcined precursors diluted in SiC (1:3 ratio), under 30000 mL h−1 g−1 space velocity. The catalysts were evaluated using two limiting temperatures, the first up to 500 °C and the second up to 225 °C (see details in Table 1). These tests were preliminary, and the best catalyst was evaluated at 350 ºC, for 16 h, for stability assessment. CO2 conversion (X) and CH4 selectivity (SCH4 ) were calculated according to equations (1) and (2), where FCO2 , FCH4 and FCO are the molar flow rates of gases outlet the reactor and FCO2,i is the inlet flow rate at room temperature. (1) X ( % ) = F C O 2 , i − F C O 2 F C O 2 , i × 100 (2) S C H 4 ( % ) = F C H 4 F C H 4 + F C O 2 × 100 Several kinetic models were reported for CO2 methanation [21], two of them being power-law models, shown in Equation (3) and (4), proposed by Chiang and Hopper [22] and by Solc [23]. In these equations k is the specific reaction rate, PCO2 and PH2 are the partial pressure of CO2 and H2, respectively. Both models were proposed for nickel-based catalysts, the first at high pressure, and the second one at atmospheric pressure. In the first equation, the reaction order is 0.66 for CO2 and 0.21 for H2, which indicates little influence of H2 on the reaction rate. The second one only considers the contribution of CO2. This last model was selected to calculate the reaction rate ( r C H 4 ) from the conversions. For determining k, the molar balance in an ideal tubular reactor was used (see Equation (5)), where X is the fractional conversion and W is the catalyst weight. The result of the integration of the equations (4) and (5) provides the specific rate constant, k, shown in Equation (6). This is shown in the Supplementary Material. The initial reaction rate (i.e. reaction rate at null conversion) was determined by Equation (7), using the obtained k values. Moreover, the intrinsic initial reaction rate was calculated by Equation (8), where SNi is the specific area of ​​the active phase. (3) r C H 4 = k P C O 2 0.66 P H 2 0.21 (4) r C H 4 = k P C O 2 0.50 (5) F C O 2 , i d X d W = r C H 4 (6) k = 2 F C O 2 , i ( P C O 2 , i ) 0.5 W [ 1 − ( 1 − X ) 0.5 ] (7) r 0 = k P C O 2 , i 0.50 (8) r ′ 0 = r 0 s N i 3 Results and Discussion 3.1 Characterization of the precursors 3.1.1 Chemical composition ICP-AES results for the calcined materials are shown in Table 2 . The molar ratios can be taken as the same as those of the precursors, since there is no sublimation of the metals (Ni, Mn and Al) under the conditions of calcination. Most experimental values of Ni, Mn and Al contents were close to the nominal ones, indicating that the synthesis conditions were adequate to precipitate the elements. However, the sample with only Ni and Mn presented the mole fraction of Mn equal to 0.13 when 0.20 was expected, therefore, 35 % of the Mn was not precipitated. In addition, the precipitation of Mn compounds was strongly influenced by pH. The trimetallic material obtained at pH 6.5 (Ni3MnAl-pH6.5-c) presented only 30 % of the initial Mn (mole fraction of 0.06 vs 0.20). According to the literature [16,24], LDH is formed at intermediate pH values between those required for the precipitation of the monometallic hydroxides, i.e., in the Ni-Mn-Al system, it would precipitate between 3.9 and 8.5, which are, respectively, the precipitation pH of Al and of Mn hydroxides in a 0.01M solution of the respective salts. The use of a pH much lower than that of the manganese hydroxide may have hampered the precipitation of manganese in Ni3MnAl-pH6.5 [25]. 3.1.2 Structural and morphological analysis Fig. 2 (a) e (b) show the XRD data of the precursors. For all materials characteristic peaks of LDH structures were identified, corresponding to the mineral takovite (Ni6Al2(OH)16)(CO3).4H2O, PDF 00-015-0087). LDH formation in the Ni4Mn-pH8 sample (Fig. 2 (a)) indicates that one of the elements adopted the oxidation state +3, most probably Mn, although it may not be excluded that Mn2+ is also present in this structure. The Mn3+ ion only exists in solution at very low pH. So, at the pH range employed in the coprecipitation, Mn2+ is the predominant species. In alkali medium, Mn2+ salt solutions precipitate as Mn(OH)2, which is known to be readily oxidized in the presence of oxygen. Similarly to LDH, Mn(OH)2 has the brucite structure, where Mn is octahedrally coordinated by hydroxyl anions [26]. Thus, the oxidation of Mn2+ in the LDH structure may be represented by the equation below: 2[Mn2+]oct + ½ O2 + H2O ↔ 2[Mn3+]oct + 2OH− (Reaction 4) where [Mn2+]oct and [Mn3+]oct stand for a Mn cation at an LDH octahedral site. The phase segregation observed in Ni3MnAl-pH8 and Ni2Mn2Al-pH8 solids (Fig. 2(b)), which are composed mainly by the expected LDH, but also contain rhodochrosite and alumina (γ-Al2O3, PDF 00-047-1292) impurity phases, may be related to the segregation of Mn, which would result from an excess of trivalent metals in LDH, creating an instability in the LDH structure, due to the increase in the electrostatic repulsion between neighboring trivalent cations, and favor the formation of other phases, such as carbonates and hydroxides [16]. In addition, the Jahn-Teller distortion associated with Mn3+ could also favor the phase segregation [16,27]. These solids would have the maximum contents (40 and 60 %, respectively) of trivalent metals (Mn + Al), if all Mn had precipitated as trivalent, see Table 2. This is above the maximum possible content of trivalent metals in the LDH layer without phase segregation, with carbonate as the interlayer anion, which is 33 % (x ≤ 0.33) [16]. There was an increase in rhodochrosite (MnCO3) impurity as the Mn content in the solids increases (Fig. 2(b)). Rietveld refinement was performed to quantify the segregated phases and to estimate the amount of di- and trivalent metals present in the trimetallic materials. The results can be seen in Table 3 and Figure S2 of the Supplementary Material. The Ni-Al LDH (ICSD 290927), rhodochrosite (ICSD 8433) and γ-Al2O3 (ICSD 291495) were used as model structures. Table S2 in the Supplementary Material shows the unit cell and the space group parameters of these model phases. The overlapping of the calculated and experimental curves (Figure S2) suggests a good quality of refinement, which was confirmed by the low GoF and Rwp values presented in Table 3. Analyzing the site occupancy in the LDH, the maximum content of trivalent metals (x) in the structure of the LDH was 0.35 (for Ni2Mn2Al-pH8), slightly higher than the limiting value cited in literature [16]. It was found that Ni3MnAl-pH8 is composed of 96 % of LDH and 4 % of rhodochrosite, while Ni2Mn2Al-pH8 contained 82 % of LDH, 15 % of rhodochrosite and 3 % of γ-Al2O3. Moreover, the site occupancy of trivalent metals (Table 3) above the Al total content (see Table 2) indicates that there was incorporation of another trivalent metal in LDH, most probably Mn3+. A mass balance was performed to estimate the Mn speciation between Mn3+ and Mn2+ in the LDH phase. For this calculation, the elemental analysis (Table 2), phase composition and site occupancy (2nd to 6th columns of Table 3) were used. The results are shown in Table 3. The larger amount of Mn3+ in Ni3MnAl-pH8 as compared to Ni3MnAl-pH6.5 does not imply a preference for Mn3+ at the higher pH, it is a consequence of the larger amount of Mn incorporated into the LDH. The increase in Mn content (Table 2) caused an almost proportional increase in Mn3+ in LDH, from 0.11 in Ni3MnAl-pH8 to 0.19 in Ni2Mn2Al-pH8. Furthermore, Mn2+, that was not detected in Ni3MnAl-pH6.5, appears in appreciable amounts in Ni3MnAl-pH8 and Ni2Mn2Al-pH8. This may be a result of some reversal of the equilibrium shown in Reaction 4 above, but it must be considered that a small amount of Mn2+ in Ni3MnAl-pH6.5 may have remained undetected by the method used, due to the small overall amount of Mn in the LDH structure. Thermogravimetric analyses (Figure S3) and FTIR spectra (Figure S4) of precursors, showed typical characteristics of LDH. The decomposition occurred in two stages for the samples with only the LDH phase [28–30]. The FTIR spectra showed bands for hydroxyl stretching [31,32], carbonate [16,33], water [34,35] and metal-oxygen bonds [36]. More detailed descriptions are presented in the Supplementary Material. The FEG-SEM images of the precursors are shown in Fig. 3 . All solids, except Mn4Al-pH8, presented an agglomerate granular morphology with sizes smaller than 1 μm, while the Mn4Al-pH8 precursor showed a foliated morphology. Moreover, incrustations of parallelepipeds (with sizes bigger than 1 μm) were observed in the precursors with the highest Mn content (Ni3MnAl-pH8, Ni2Mn2Al-pH8 and Mn4Al-pH8), suggesting that those particles might be associated with the MnCO3 impurity. The trimetallic precursor prepared at a lower pH produced a more uniform and unique morphology, as seen in the image of Ni3MnAl-pH6.5. This can be related to the influence of pH on the kinetics of the precipitation. For Ni4Mn-pH8, there are also particles with fibrous morphology, together with the aggregates. This intergrowth could be correlated with the overlapping of diffraction peaks of these samples, particularly between 30 and 60 º, characteristic of stacking faults. 3.2 Characterization of the calcined precursors 3.2.1 Structural analysis Fig. 2(c) and (d) shows the diffractograms of the calcined precursors and the patterns for NiO (PDF 00-047-1049), ε-MnO2 (PDF 00-030-0820), Mn2O3 (PDF 00-006-0540) and δ-MnO2. The XRD patterns for monometallic oxides (NiO and MnO2) are shown in Figure S5 of the Supplementary Material. All diffractograms of nickel-containing samples showed characteristic peaks of nickel oxide. An additional peak is observed at 2θ ≈ 56° in Ni3MnAl-pH8-c and Ni2Mn2Al-pH8-c XRD, that may be associated with the ε-MnO2 structure, resulting from the decomposition of MnCO3. In the upper part of the figure, a zoom of this region is exhibited. The peak displacement at 2θ ≈ 63° (see dashed line in Fig. 2(d)) to higher angles for the NiO phase indicates a contraction of the a parameter of the unit cell, resulting from the substitution of Ni2+ (0.690 Å) by smaller ions such as Al3+ (0.535 Å), Mn3+ (0.645 Å) or Mn4+ (0.530 Å) [37], indicating the formation of mixed oxides. The Rietveld refinement was performed to determine the unit cell parameter (a), to calculate the NiO crystallite size and to quantify the crystalline phases. The NiO (ICSD 9866), MnO2 (ICSD 76430) and Mn2O3 (ICSD 643197) patterns were used as model structures (Table S2 in the Supplementary Material). The results of the refinement as cell parameter, phase composition and fitting quality parameters can be seen in Table S3 and Figure S6. Moreover, Fig. 4 shows the variation of a cell parameter with the Ni content, from which is clear that there is a contraction of the unit cell with the decrease in Ni content. This contraction was more pronounced when Mn and Al were inserted together in the lattice. Table 4 exhibits the crystallite size of NiO phase in the calcined precursor, where the bimetallic and trimetallic oxides have smaller sizes than monometallic NiO. 3.2.2 Reducibility of calcined samples Fig. 5 shows the H2-TPR profiles of the oxides. The vertical solid lines identify the main reduction maxima and the dotted one marks the beginning of the 1 h isotherm at 500 °C. Only Ni and Mn are reducible under the conditions of analysis and can produce metallic nickel (Ni0) and manganese (II) oxide (MnO). Several stages of reduction are observed, characterized by peaks and shoulders, which indicate different types of interactions of metals in the solids. For the monometallic oxide (NiO), the maximum H2 consumption occurred at 393 °C with a reduction in a single step. This is consistent with the hydrogen consumption during H2-TPR, which was very close to the value required to reduce 100 % of Ni2+ to Ni0. This profile is similar to others found in the literature [38]. For the LDH-derived bimetallic oxides which contain only NiO as a crystalline phase (Ni4Al-pH6.5-c and Ni4Mn-pH8-c), a displacement of the reduction peak to higher temperature was observed when compared to bulk NiO. This is probably the result of the interaction of nickel with the neighboring aluminum or manganese phases, caused by a higher dispersion of the NiO phase [39]. This is confirmed by the crystallographic results, which showed that the Ni4Al-pH6.5-c and Ni4Mn-pH8-c crystallites are smaller than those in bulk NiO (Table 4). Stronger interactions between nickel and aluminum or nickel and manganese ions may result from the polarization effect of the trivalent ions (Al3+ and Mn3+) on the Ni-O bond [6,17]. In Mn4Al-pH8-c, containing δ–MnO2 and Mn3O4 phases, a wide variety of reduction temperatures was observed, with H2 consumption peaks at 283 and 393 °C. According to a previous work [36], the first peak can be associated with δ-MnO2 reduction and the last one with Mn3O4 reduction. The H2-TPR results for trimetallic oxides show that the presence of the three metals in the solids produces peaks and shoulders below 300 ºC. This suggests a synergy not observed in bimetallic oxides, except for Mn4Al-pH8-c. This finding was also observed by other authors [5,32] during the reduction of mixed oxides with more than two metals. Two types of reduction profiles for the trimetallic oxides can be noticed: one for the solid without MnCO3 in the precursor (Ni3MnAl-pH6.5-c) and another one for those containing this compound (Ni3MnAl-pH8-c and Ni2Mn2Al-pH8-c). The first group has two reduction events, one below 234 °C and the other at 500 °C. In the second group, there is a third stage around 380 ºC, that must arise from the reduction of the ε-MnO2 oxide generated from the decomposition of MnCO3. 3.2.3 Textural analysis of calcined samples By analyzing the N2 adsorption results for the mixed oxides (Table 4), it was observed that both aluminum and manganese acted as textural promoters. The increase in the surface area was of one order of magnitude, as can be seen by comparing the area of monometallic NiO (<10 m² g−1) with the bimetallic oxides Ni4Al-pH6.5-c (164 m² g−1) and Ni4Mn-pH8-c (107 m² g−1). Other authors have also reported an increase in the surface area of mixed oxides when Al or Mn were added to nickel oxide [25]. The solids containing Ni and Al presented the highest surface areas, indicating that the Ni-Al combination is more effective in textural promotion than the Ni-Mn one. 3.3 Characterization of the reduced samples 3.3.1 Structural and morphological analysis The diffractograms of passivated and reduced monometallic catalysts (NiO-r and MnO2-r) showed only characteristic peaks of Ni0 or MnO phases, respectively, and are illustrated in Figure S5 of the Supplementary Material. The absence of NiO and manganese oxide with an oxidation state above +2 suggests that the passivation was adequate to protect the catalysts against spontaneous oxidation by air. Fig. 2 ((e) - (f)) shows the diffractograms of passivated and reduced catalysts and the NiO, MnO (PDF 01-080-8705) and Ni0 (PDF 00-004-0850) XRD patterns. The phase composition of the reduced materials, the a parameter and the crystallite size of metallic nickel were obtained through Rietveld refinement (Table 5 and Figure S6). The Ni a parameter showed a small contraction when Al and Mn were incorporated, which may be due to the inclusion of a small quantity of other metals in the crystal lattice. On the other hand, a drastic decrease in the size of the Ni metal crystallites (dNi ) is observed when Mn and Al are incorporated, separately or simultaneously. Furthermore, the nickel degree of reduction (α) and the nickel surface area (SNi ) were also determined with Rietveld refinement data, as described in the Supplementary Materials, and are exhibited in Table 5. A decrease in Ni degree of reduction was observed for the catalysts with Al in comparison with the aluminum-free one: the reduction degree diminished from 100 % to around 60 %. This demonstrates that Al generated Ni2+ species, which are more difficult to reduce. Although NiO-r and Ni4Mn-pH8-r have the highest Ni° content (100 and 81 wt%), they have the lowest metallic nickel surface area, only 1.8 and 10.6 m2 of Ni0 per gram of catalyst, which represents less than 50 % of the nickel surface in trimetallic catalysts and Ni4Al-pH6.5-r. Although Mn facilitated the onset of the reduction of trimetallic catalysts, there was no significant influence on the Ni reduction degree: all are in the same range (54 to 64 %) as Ni4Al-pH6.5 (59 %), the solid without Mn. The TEM micrographs of selected catalysts (Ni4Mn-pH8-r, Ni4Al-pH6.5-r and Ni3MnAl-pH6.5-r) are shown in Fig. 6 , along with selected area electron diffraction (SAED) patterns and high-resolution TEM (HRTEM) micrographs. The particle size distributions are presented as insets in the TEM micrographs. For all samples, the particles are approximately spherical, and the dispersions are not homogeneous, with some agglomerates. Especially for Ni4Al-pH6.5-r and Ni3MnAl-pH6.5-r, shown in Fig. 6 ((b) and (c)), these clusters appear to align in fillets. As found in XRD data, the samples Ni4Al-pH6.5-r and Ni3MnAl-pH6.5-r show significant decreases in particle size that can be associated with the insertion of Al or Mn into the crystal lattice. The particle sizes obtained by TEM micrographs are of the same order as the crystallite sizes determined by XRD, suggesting that most particles possess one crystallite. The HRTEM micrographs were used to determine some crystal planes and interplanar distances of Ni particles, suggesting the <111> direction as preferential. The SAED patterns are also in agreement with the XRD results, suggesting that there is more than one crystalline phase in the materials. For the Ni4Mn-pH8-r sample, the diffraction spots can be indexed to the planes of the MnO crystalline phases (PDF 01-080-8705) and Ni0 (PDF 00-004-0850) while for Ni4Al-pH6.5-r and Ni3MnAl-pH6.5-r, all diffraction rings are indexed to the crystalline phase planes of NiO (PDF 00-047-1049) and the Ni0 (PDF 00-004-0850). The absence of other diffraction spots or rings in all samples confirms that there were no phases other than the intended material. 3.3.2 Basicity measurements The CO2-TPD profiles for the catalysts are shown in Fig. 7 . The dashed line indicates the start of the isotherm at 500 °C. Most of the profiles exhibited two CO2 evolution regions, one close to 100 °C and the other one between 170 and 400 °C. Table 6 and Figure S8 show the results of the deconvolution of the CO2-TPD profiles. The CO2 desorption at around 100 ºC is attributed to the decomposition of bidentate carbonates from CO2 adsorption on surface hydroxyl groups or on unreduced metals [40,41], both being considered weak basic sites [5]. The second range of evolution comprises two stages of CO2 release, one around 180 °C and the other above 250 °C. The former is associated with the desorption of CO2 adsorbed on Ni particles [41] and the latter adsorbed on Lewis acid-base pairs [42]. Despite the temperature difference, both are considered moderate strength sites, since strong basic sites only release CO2 above 400 °C [43,44]. The only solid that showed strong basic sites was the reference material MnO2-r, which released CO2 at 500 °C. These sites are associated with CO2 desorption from low-coordination O2− ions forming monodentate carbonate, which is more stable, so it is less reactive, and only decomposes at high temperatures [43,44]. According to literature, with the increasing temperature (above 400 °C), the RWGS reaction is favored over methanation and the thermodynamic limitations impose a significant drop in the conversion [11,40]. Therefore, the weak (100 °C) and moderate (around 215 and 340 °C) basic sites found in the synthesized catalysts seem appropriate for the reaction. By comparing the basicity between the bimetallic and trimetallic solids, it is observed that the addition of a new metal (Ni, Mn or Al) in the bimetallic catalysts generated an increase in the basicity, especially of the moderate basic sites. Table 6 shows the total amount of CO2 desorbed and its distribution by temperature range. The catalysts with the lowest basicity were NiO-r and Ni4Mn-pH8-r. In the former case, this is due to the lack of a phase with adequate basicity for CO2 chemisorption and furthermore having a small surface area (cf. Table 5). In the second case, this low basicity may be related to the low dispersion (large particle size) of the MnO phase (cf. Table 5). The trimetallic solids are more basic than the others, Ni3MnAl-pH6.5-r showing the highest basicity (2.48 mmol g−1), followed by Ni2Mn2Al-pH8-r (1.81 mmol g−1) and Ni3MnAl-pH8-r (1.19 mmol g−1). The highest basicity of the Ni3MnAl-pH6.5-r may be associated with the preparation method, since it was the only solid obtained at pH 6.5 (among the trimetallic solids), resulting in a mixed oxide with the lowest manganese content, 6 mol% (see Table 2) and the highest dispersion of Mn since no crystalline phases associated with this element could be observed in the XRD (see Fig. 2 (e)-(f)). Xiao et al. [5] observed the same behavior when analyzing the influence of Mn content on the basicity of catalysts containing Ni, Mn, Mg and Al. In this study, the solid with 5 % Mn adsorbed more CO2 than those with 10 and 15 mol% Mn. For the solids with similar MnO dispersion, Ni2Mn2Al-pH8-r and Ni3MnAl-pH8-r, whose MnO crystallite size was 6 nm, the basicity increased with increasing MnO content. Vrijburg et al. [6,20] also observed the direct relationship between the basicity and the amount of manganese in solids. They reported that increased basicity in catalysts containing manganese is associated with oxygen vacancies originating in MnO clusters during the reduction step. These vacancies facilitate the adsorption CO2 on the catalyst surface. 3.4 Catalysts evaluation Fig. 8 shows the CO2 conversion and methane selectivity for the catalysts and the thermodynamic equilibrium conversion curve, calculated by minimizing the Gibbs energy using the Aspen Plus software. The thermodynamic equilibrium curve represents the maximum conversion as a function of pressure and temperature. The horizontal line signals the conversion of 50 % of CO2. It is worth remembering that, under the test conditions, both methanation and RWGS may occur. Three distinct activity patterns of behavior were identified among the catalysts. The first one was obtained over the catalyst without nickel (MnO2-r and Mn4Al-pH8-r). In this case, the activities started only above 300 °C, reaching 30 % conversion at 500 °C (Fig. 8(a)), the selectivity to methane being below 50 % (Fig. 8(b)). This behavior indicates that their active sites are more suitable for RWGS than for methanation. The addition of Al to the Mn oxide caused complete inhibition of methanation, as seen from the Mn4Al-pH8-r results. The low activity of this group highlights the importance of Ni in methanation. The second type of profile was obtained over the catalysts with the highest nickel contents and fully reduced Ni (cf. Table 4), NiO-r and Ni4Mn-pH8-r, which were more active and selective to methane than the first group. Despite the high content of Ni0 species (active phase), their CO2 conversion (started at around 250 °C) did not exceed 50 % at 500 °C. The low activities of these catalysts may be associated with the large metallic nickel crystallite sizes, and therefore low surface area of the active phase (Table 5). Unlike NiO-r, Ni4Mn-pH8-r maintained 100 % selectivity to methane up to 400 °C, showing that the addition of Mn to nickel oxide promoted selectivity to CH4 at low temperatures. Finally, the third group is formed by the trimetallic catalysts and Ni4Al-pH6.5-r, all of them having metallic nickel crystallite sizes below 6 nm and weight composition between 38 and 53 % of active phase (Ni0). The conversions started at 150 °C, reaching maximum conversion (82 %) around 350 °C, followed by a drop to approximately 58 %. The thermodynamic equilibrium curve indicates that the decrease in catalytic activity occurred due to thermodynamic limitations and not to physical or chemical deactivation. The inclusion of manganese shifted the curves to lower temperatures. Vrijburg et al [6,20] identified, through in situ IR spectroscopy, that Mn-doped nickel catalysts adsorb CO2 at lower temperatures, generating intermediates such as carbonyls and formates that did not exist in the Mn-free catalyst and that the increase in Mn content produced more of these intermediates. Thus, the presence of MnO promotes the CO2 methanation mechanism where also bicarbonate/formate species play a role, facilitating the reaction at lower temperatures [6,20]. However, in our work, the conversion diminished with the catalysts with higher manganese content, indicating that there is an optimal value for the replacement of Ni by Mn. The catalysts of the third group were 100 % selective to methane up to 400 °C. Above this temperature, a decrease of methane selectivity to ca. 85 % was observed due to CO formation on the Ni4Al-pH6.5-r, Ni3MnAl-pH6.5-r and Ni3MnAl-pH8-r solids. The material with the highest Mn contents (Ni2Mn2Al-pH8-r) maintained methane selectivity at 100 % during the time on stream, proving to be more selective than other catalysts found in literature. For example, Co-based catalysts with spinel structure showed 80 % and 50 % methane selectivity at 400 and 550 °C, respectively [9]. The LDH-derived mixed oxides in the Ni-Mg-Al system showed 80 % of selectivity at 500 °C [15]. As for nickel-based supported catalysts, it was observed that on Al2O3 [4], Al2O3-SiO2 [45] and ceramic monoliths [46] the selectivity was lower than 90 % at 500 °C. They are also more selective than LDH-derived bulk catalysts, whose selectivity decreased above 350 °C due to carbon deposition [47] or CO formation [17]. Varga et al. [9] reported that formate production at the Co/Mn2+ interface in spinel catalyst (MnCo2O4) is mostly responsible for methane formation at high temperature. As mentioned before, Vrijburg et al [20] identified that the MnO phase promotes the formation of formates from 50 °C, so it is likely that the selectivity of 100 % at 500 °C is associated with a predominance of a mechanism involving these species. To compare the results of this study with those in the literature, the temperature at which 50 % conversion is reached (T50) was used to evaluate the catalytic activity at low temperatures (Table 6). The Ni3MnAl-pH6.5-r and Ni3MnAl-pH8-r catalysts achieved 50 % conversion at 248 °C, 34 °C below the T50 of Ni4Al-pH6.5-r. This value was lower than the T50 obtained in the studies by Xiao et al. [5] and Tamimi et al [4], who worked with lower Ni contents. The former worked with Ni-Mg-Mn-Al oxides from LDH (T50 = 263 °C) and the later used NiO-Al2O3 doped with different levels of Mn (T50 > 250°). A comparative table of catalytic activity of the different nickel-based catalysts reported in the literature and the best catalyst in this work (Ni3MnAl-pH6.5-r) is presented in the Supplementary Material (Table S4). From the data for T50, conversion of CO2 and selectivity to CH4, it is possible to see that, in general, our catalyst (Ni3MnAl-pH6.5-r) had a better activity for the same level of selectivity; its performance, at maximum conversion temperature (350 °C), is comparable to some recently reported Ni-based catalysts [5,17,20,48]. However, at low temperature (225 °C), it is better than most of the catalysts in Table S4 [4,5,20,40,48–51]. As seen from the evaluation up to 500 °C, CO2 conversion decreases at temperatures above ca. 350 ºC, closely following the expected thermodynamic equilibrium curve for CO2 methanation. Below this temperature, the reaction is kinetically limited, and conversion increases with increasing temperature. Thus, it is essential to work at a temperature that favors kinetics, without greatly reducing equilibrium conversion and methane selectivity. The results of tests up to 500 ºC show that this temperature should be less than 400 ºC. The reaction was then carried out at a constant temperature of 225 ºC (Fig. 9 ), a condition far from thermodynamic equilibrium, over trimetallic catalysts and bimetallic Ni4Al-pH6.5-r. It was found that all catalysts remained active after 4 h of reaction, allowing to determine the mean steady-state conversion, shown in Table 6. From these data, the promotion effect of Mn was confirmed, by the increase in conversion from 14 (Ni4Al-pH6.5-r, without Mn and with higher active phase content), to 40 % (Ni3MnAl-pH6.5-r, 6 mol% of Mn). This improved activity can be associated with the greater capacity of the catalysts to adsorb CO2, due to a larger number of basic sites, and smaller nickel crystallites sizes, thus resulting in more active catalysts even with lower active phase content. However, further increase in Mn content (cf. Table 2 for actual Mn content) caused a decrease in conversion to 35 % (Ni3MnAl-pH8-r, 19 mol% Mn) and 25 % (Ni2Mn2Al-pH8-r, 41 mol% Mn). It is worth remembering that Mn replaced Ni in the solids; therefore, an increase in the Mn content implies a lower amount of Ni (active phase) and this is certainly an important reason that caused the reduction in conversion with the increase in Mn content. Analyzing the intrinsic reaction rate results with respect to Ni surface area (Table 6), it is seen that they were essentially the same for three of the Mn-containing catalysts, but that of the Mn-free catalyst is about 1/3 of the intrinsic activity of the Mn-containing ones. An important conclusion can be derived: regardless of the amount of Mn, the activity per area of metallic nickel varies little, that is, the phase responsible for the methanation activity is metallic Ni. However, a minimum amount of Mn is necessary to increase activity, as demonstrated by the comparison between the intrinsic reaction rates of Ni4Al-pH6.5-r and Ni3MnAl-pH6.5-r, which have 0 and 6 mol % of Mn in the oxides. Vrijburg et al. [6] also reported that the intrinsic methanation activity remained constant per active site regardless of the Ni/Mn ratio. The stability tests were carried out over the best catalyst (Ni3MnAl-pH6.5-r) at 350 °C (where the maximum conversion is reached) for 16 h. The results are presented in Fig. 10 . The catalyst proved to be stable, keeping the activity and selectivity during time-on-stream (XCO2 = 82 % e SCH4 = 100 %). The stability test profile of this material is similar to that of other nickel-based LDH catalysts [5,17,49]. The spent catalyst was characterized by XRD, SEM and TGA and the results were compared with those of the fresh catalyst. In Fig. 11 , small differences in both structure and morphology of Ni3MnAl-pH6.5-r catalyst can be seen. The spent catalyst consists mainly of Ni0 and NiO and, a very small amount of LDH phase. The formation of LDH is a consequence of memory effects that are favored by the presence of H2O (product of reaction 1) and CO2 (reactant) in the reactor. These effects are typical of LDH oxides that, when hydrated, return to the LDH form [52]. According to Abate et al. [17], catalysts from LDH have higher stability than the commercial catalyst, which is based on Ni deposited on Al2O3, due to a lower sintering of the material. In fact, no significant change in particle size was identified through XRD and SEM analyses after the CO2 methanation reaction. Thermal analysis of fresh and spend catalyst (see Figure S9) shows a nearly constant mass above 450 ºC, indicating that there was no significant coke formation during the tests. The catalyst remained almost unchanged after the reaction during 16 h at 350 °C, confirming its high thermal stability. 4 Conclusions Ni-Mn-Al LDH were successfully synthesized under the conditions investigated, pH 8 being more suitable than pH 6.5 for metal precipitation. The characterization of Ni-Mn bimetallic LDH indicates that Mn can precipitate both as Mn2+ and Mn3+. It was also demonstrated that, in Al containing materials, Mn is present partly in the +3 state. The increase in Mn content resulted in precursors with phase segregation (LDH, MnCO3 and/or Al2O3) that, when calcined, generated mixed oxides with NiO, Mn2O3 and MnO2 phases. The addition of manganese enhanced the surface area, metal reducibility and CO2 adsorption capacity, increasing the catalytic activity. At 225 ºC, the maximum conversion was 40 % over the catalyst containing 6 mol% Mn, in the precursor oxide. When the Mn content reached 41 mol% (Ni2Mn2Al-pH8-r), the conversion was nearly halved (25 %). Even then, this value was higher than the conversion over the Mn-free catalyst (14 %). At 500 °C, the Mn-richest catalyst inhibited the RWGS reaction (thermodynamically favored at high temperatures), resulting in a CH4 selectivity of 100 %. The intrinsic activity values suggest that the main factor that influences the specific activity of the trimetallic catalysts is the metallic nickel surface area. The best catalyst, Ni3MnAl-pH6.5-r, remained active during 16 h on stream at 350 °C, with no decrease in performance (XCO2 = 82 % and SCH4 = 100 %). It suggests that there was no coke formation on the catalyst and that the structural and morphological transformations were insignificant. Therefore, it is shown that NiMnAl LDH, low-cost materials, easy to obtain and with high potential for scaling, are promising precursors for high-performance non-precious metal catalysts in CO2 methanation, Mn being an important promoter in this reaction. This catalyst has environmental significance due to its potential use in a reaction that uses CO2 (greenhouse gas) to produce synthetic fuel. Future work may focus on verifying whether lower Mn loads or the replacement of Al by Mn, while keeping the Ni content constant, can further enhance catalytic activity for the CO2 hydrogenation reaction. coredata.dc:description: It is widely agreed among researchers that global warming is directly linked to increased concentrations of carbon dioxide (CO2) in the atmosphere. As such, technologies aimed at reducing CO2 emissions have been extensively studied. In this study, bimetallic (Ni-Mn, Ni-Al, Mn-Al) and trimetallic (Ni-Mn-Al) precursors were synthesized by a coprecipitation method to obtain layered double hydroxides (LDH). Preparation of the studied catalysts is easily scalable, due to the relative simplicity and reproducibility of LDH synthesis. The effects of pH and molar proportion of the metals on their physical and chemical properties were evaluated. After calcination and in-situ reduction, the oxides were evaluated as catalysts in the CO2 hydrogenation reaction, which is a possible alternative to the abatement of global warming. It was concluded that Mn increased the specific surface area of the oxides and the content of basic sites in the catalyst, as well as facilitated the onset of the materials reduction. The most active catalyst, obtained at lower pH, had only 6 mol% Mn and showed CO2 conversion and CH4 selectivity equal to 82 % and 100 % at 350 °C, respectively. It was also stable during 16 h on stream, at the temperature of maximum conversion. At low temperatures, this catalyst was one of the best reported in the literature, with CO2 conversion and CH4 selectivity of 40 % and 100 % at 225 °C, respectively. Additionally, 50 % conversion was achieved at 248 °C (T50). At temperatures higher than 400 °C, the reverse water gas shift reaction, which competes with methanation, was inhibited in solids with higher Mn contents (≥ 40 mol%).
